awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: A Multilevel Analysis of Youth Crime
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project, the effects of school-level, neighborhood-level, and individual level variables on youth crime are analyzed using a dataset that is combined from a multi-level survey and the Census.  This study addresses the complex issue of adolescent crime in contemporary society by taking into account youth capacity to make decisions and by examining adolescents in different areas in the U.S. in the 21st century.  It considers contemporary adolescent crime as a product of the interrelationship between decision-making and various social contexts in youth life including school environment, neighborhood milieu, family dynamics, and other important domains. Results from this project will help develop recommendations for youth crime reduction strategies and will facilitate collaborations between sociologists, criminologists, educators, decision makers, and other stakeholders on strategies concerning adolescent crime prevention. 

This analysis will use a unique dataset constructed by combining data from a recently conducted multi-level survey of over 2,000 middle and high school students from 40 schools in several metropolitan areas in the U. S. (ISRD, Wave III), the U.S. Census, and the National Center for Education Statistics.  Different types of quantitative analyses will be employed, such as multi-level modeling, to address the cross-level interactional effects of predictors on adolescent crime.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Anastasiia Timmer has completed research for her dissertation "A Multilevel Analysis of Youth Crime." Her project focused on causes of adolescent violence and crime in contemporary society. Adolescent violence has been on the minds of many in the United States as there have been numerous school shootings throughout the past years. Other incidents of youth crime including hacking, digital pirating, and vandalism have also become widespread. While researchers recognized the vulnerability of individuals during the adolescent life period, they have primarily focused on adolescents as passive actors. This project has taken into account the role of youth capacity to make decisions Specifically, using contemporary data from adolescents in several metropolitan areas in the U.S., it explored whether adolescent crime is a product of the interrelationship between decision-making and various social contexts in youth life including family and school environments, neighborhood milieu, and other critical domains of life.

To examine causes of youth crime, Timmer integrated several novel perspectives in criminology and sociology including the hot/cool perspective of criminal decision-making and the Situational Action Theory and extended their main ideas by focusing on a variety of individual and contextual effects on adolescent crime. To answer the research questions, she constructed a novel dataset combining the survey data from adolescents in several U.S. metropolitan areas collected in 2014-2017 (ISRD3) as well as the data from the National Center for Education Statistics (NCES), and the US Census and American Community Survey and conducted a series of quantitative analyses appropriate for criminal behavior as the outcome (e.g., modeling using negative binomial regression, multi-level modeling).

First, findings of this project illustrate that different cool factors such as youth ability to be thoughtful and reflective when making decisions prevents young people from committing various types of crime including violence, property crime, and cybercrime. Further, a variety of hot triggers such as conditions empowering affective and emotional responses significantly influence the likelihood of adolescent criminal engagement. In addition, whereas several normative-affective triggers such as stressful life conditions and alcohol decrease the crime protective effects of rational decision-making, positive emotions and morality amplify these crime-protective effects. Taken together, these findings confirm that the processes related to individual agency and youth crime are complex, and different interactive effects need to be taken into account to better conceptualize causes of adolescent delinquency in contemporary society.

Further, in the multi-level component of this project, Timmer contextualized youth agency and focused on the effects of several important contexts in youth life such as school and neighborhood on criminal involvement. First, results from the study demonstrate that several school characteristics including school moral, sanctioning, and thoughtfully reflective climates interact with individual criminal propensity (i.e., morality and self-control) in their effects on adolescent delinquency. Specifically, school moral, sanctioning, and thoughtfully reflective climates have stronger effects on criminal behavior among adolescents with lower criminal propensity. These findings suggest that adolescents do not benefit from their environments equally and policies focused on the school context need to be more nuanced taking into account differential adolescent propensities. Results of the study also show that neighborhood characteristics such as poverty tend to affect certain types of youth crime but not others. Overall, whereas generally the findings from this project illuminate a potentially more salient influence of the school as opposed to the neighborhood environment on adolescent criminal behavior, the results from additional analyses suggest more complex mechanisms linking neighborhoods and contemporary youth crime.

Taken together, the findings of this project set the foundation for an integrated theory of juvenile criminal behavior with a more nuanced understanding of the interrelationships between different aspects of individual agency and contextual dynamics. The specific outcomes of this study include a dissertation and conference presentations as well as several articles submitted or in preparation to be submitted to established peer-reviewed outlets. In addition, reports based on the study results are currently in preparation to be submitted to schools to inform school officials, educators, and other stakeholders on the extent of student criminal behavior as well as important aspects of youth life affecting deviance. Finally, Timmer plans to work on further refining integrated criminological and interdisciplinary theories and designing more nuanced studies of causes of youth crime in the U.S. and cross-nationally.
